ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

DELAYED DISBURSEMENT OF ANNUAL GRANT TO SINGAPORE ATHLETIC ASSOCIATION

(Impact)

     1.  Mr Seah Kian Peng asked the Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports in view of the disagreement between the Singapore Sports Council (SSC) and the Singapore Athletic Association (SAA) (a) whether mediation can provide a possible resolution; (b) what is the impact on

Column: 2829

athletes from the delayed disbursement of the annual grant of almost $900,000 to SAA; and (c) whether this will have implications on our hosting of the Youth Olympic Games and other future major athletics events.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports (Mr Teo Ser Luck) (for the Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports):  Mr Speaker, Sir, the Singapore Sports Council (SSC) administers the disbursement of grants to National Sports Associations (NSAs), to help them promote and develop their respective sports in Singapore. As part of due process, SSC requires NSAs to submit their sports development plans for SSC's consideration before the disbursement of funds. NSAs are also required to demonstrate that they have in place sound governance and administration structures, as monetary grants are involved.  In evaluating the request for grants, SSC will also look at whether the NSA has been able to fulfil past targets that the NSA has set.

 

     The Singapore Athletic Association (SAA) has not met the conditions for SSC grants.  It has not fulfilled the past targets, and the improvement plans have not been adequate.  There are also major weaknesses in governance, including some high-risk audit areas.  Therefore, SSC has withheld the disbursement of the grants for Financial Year 2010. This is a regulatory matter involving public money.  When SAA is able to meet the conditions for SSC grants, SSC will re-consider the situation and if all conditions are fulfilled, SSC will disburse the grants.

 

     Part of NSA grants goes towards supporting the training of national athletes. SSC is mindful of the possible impact on them, and is working with

Column: 2830

various stakeholders to ensure that the athletes’ training and welfare are not compromised. For example, SSC has been disbursing training assistance grants directly to athletes under training. SSC has also continued to provide sports medicine and sports science support to the athletes.  Funding is a privilege.  It is not an entitlement for NSAs.  We will not hesitate to fund the athletes directly in consideration of their welfare and funding needs.


     This episode should not have any implication for the upcoming Youth Olympic Games (YOG).  The competition managers and key staff for athletics for the YOG have already been appointed. They are in full preparation for the successful running of the athletics events for the Games. SSC has also continued to allow the YOG athletes to use Bukit Gombak Stadium for training and qualification competitions for the YOG.

     Mr Speaker:  Mr Seah, I will allow one supplementary question only.

     Mr Seah Kian Peng (Marine Parade):  Thank you, Sir.  I thank the Senior Parliamentary Secretary for his answer.  I have the following supplementary questions.  There has been much public interest in this matter and there were some calls for MCYS to get involved in addressing the leadership issue in SAA.  My first question is, should Government –

     Mr Speaker:  You have only one question, Mr Seah.

     Mr Seah Kian Peng: Should the Government play a more active role in this, or leave it to the fraternity to sort itself out?  Second, can the SSC consider direct funding to the athletes in view of this protracted negotiation, specifically for the 4 x 100-metre relay team?  Can this be done given that one of our best athletic talents in recent decades?  Third, –

Column: 2831

     Mr Speaker:  Mr Seah, I said I would allow only one question. You have gotten into your third, now.

     Mr Seah Kian Peng:  Sir, there is one portion where the Senior Parliamentary Secretary did not quite address which is the impact on future athletic events.  And just one last question, are there any other NSAs where SSC may have concerns with regard to corporate governance issues?

     Mr Speaker:  Okay, Mr Teo.  Quick answers.

     Mr Teo Ser Luck:  Sir, SSC is the governor of the sports sector in Singapore and MCYS is the policy-maker.  SSC will continue to support all the NSAs who present good development and training plans.  We are always in consultation with NSAs to see how we can best support them.  Annual funding is one way, and indirect services is another way through which we support them.  We cannot be involved in the associations' electoral process because that has to be decided by their respective fraternity. 

 

     In SAA's case, the 21 affiliates have to decide what is the best way forward for the association.  They have to decide who takes the leadership because they represent the voices of the athletic fraternity.  At the same time, they have to, not only to listen to themselves and the fraternity, but also the public voices as well.  When it comes to elections and the time to vote, they have to make the right decision.

 

     For the 4 x 100-metre relay team, I am glad that they are back in training.  If they have any needs in terms of funding and training, they can always approach SSC, and we are more than willing to give them support.  We are always willing to support any future athletic event, and we are always open to consultation and having more athletic events in Singapore.  Because in any major game, athletics is a

Column: 2832

key event and an integral part of any international multi-sports game.  We will also like Singapore to do well in this key sport.  As such, the Member can be assured that when NSAs such as SAA are able to sort their issues out, whether audit, governance or training plans, SSC will be fully supportive in terms of disbursing the grants.  As for his concerns over other NSAs with governance issues, the Member can also be assured that SSC will step up its regulatory audits and make sure that these are more regular.  We will make sure NSAs understand that when they obtain funding from SSC, they are dealing with public money.  Public money cannot be taken for granted.

CARPARKS IN NEW HDB ESTATES

(Ratio of lots to residential units)

     The following Question stood in the name of Mdm Cynthia Phua –

 

     2.  To ask the Minister for National Development (a) what is the ratio of carpark lots to the number of residential units in new HDB estates; (b) whether there are plans to increase the carpark lots in the mature estates to reflect changes in the population demographics as more HDB units now have more than one car with the children becoming working adults; and (c) whether the Ministry is planning to build any new multi-storey carparks in the older precincts in Aljunied GRC.

     Mr Seah Kian Peng:  Question No. 2.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Dr Mohamad Maliki Bin Osman) (for the Minister for National Development):  In general, HDB’s 1,800 car parks are sufficient to cater to both season parking and short term parking needs of the various housing estates.  The average season parking take-up rate in HDB car parks is about 73% currently.

 

Column: 2833

     However, due to changes in the demographic profiles and car ownership patterns, about 10% of HDB car parks are currently unable to meet local parking demand.  HDB is looking into supply as well as demand management measures to alleviate the shortages at these car parks.


     Depending on the availability of space as well as cost considerations, HDB may add parking lots by extending the existing surface car parks into adjacent vacant land, adding parking decks to existing multi-storey car parks (MSCPs), or constructing new MSCPs to replace existing surface car parks.

 

     HDB currently has no plans to construct MSCPs in Aljunied GRC as the shortfalls in parking lots at the affected locations are too small to justify the provision of MSCPs. It will look into providing additional parking lots through other means instead.

 

     There are limits to increasing car parks in land scarce Singapore. Therefore, demand management measures are also essential.  Where there are only limited parking lots for season parking ticket holders, HDB accords priority to the first car in each household. HDB also groups its car parks for season parking such that car owners living in several nearby blocks share their car park lots. 

 

     HDB will continue to monitor and manage the supply and demand for HDB car parks to address residents’ changing parking needs.

LAND LEASES FOR ESTABLISHMENT OF RETIREMENT HOMES

(Extension)

     3.  Mr Laurence Wee Yoke Thong asked the Minister for National Development whether the Government will consider extending land leases to at least 60 years

Column: 2834

or 30 years plus another 30 years for the establishment of retirement homes or villages so as to provide more residential options for the elderly.

     The Senior Minister of State for National Development (Ms Grace Fu Hai Yien) (for the Minister for National Development):  Developers can already build retirement housing on any site zoned "Residential". They can also choose to build residential developments and customise the design and concept to target specific niche markets, including the elderly.  For instance, some developers have introduced "dual-key" adjoining apartments in private condominiums.


     In addition, the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has made available a site at Jalan Jurong Kechil for sale on short tenure of 30 years.  The developer has the flexibility to develop the site for retirement housing or conventional housing development. The shorter tenure of 30 years allowed for the site was intended to reduce the land costs, which could facilitate retirement housing development.  We will study the suggestion to extend land leases to 60-year or 30+30-year tenures for such sites in future. HDB has also built Studio Apartments, which are custom-built for elderly living and made our public housing estates elderly friendly.

     Mr Laurence Wee Yoke Thong (Nominated Member): Thank you for the Senior Minister of State's reply.  We are now healthier and living longer.  A number of older persons face loneliness which cut across all income groups. Retirement villages offer a great opportunity for them to interact.  Sir, there is no supplementary question.

MOBILISATION OF COMMUNITY RESOURCES FOR FRAIL ELDERLY

(Enlistment of relatives and neighbours)

     4.  Mr Laurence Wee Yoke Thong asked the Prime Minister whether the Govern

Column: 2835

ment will consider enlisting relatives and neighbours in the mobilisation of community resources to care for the frail elderly.

     The Minister, Prime Minister's Office (Mr Lim Boon Heng) (for the Prime Minister):  The family must be the first line of care and support for the elderly.  Besides the immediate family, the extended family should lend its support.  I fully agree with Mr Laurence Wee that the community, and especially, neighbours can also play an important role.  To augment the efforts by community agencies and VWOs, we are indeed trying to encourage and mobilise informal networks to support our seniors to age-in-place.  As a Chinese saying goes, "in times of need, a relative who lives far away would not be as helpful as a neighbour".  At the minimum, neighbours can help to keep a lookout for our seniors, particularly those who may be frail, home-bound or socially isolated.  They can help the seniors with some simple tasks such as running simple errands or accompanying them for medical appointments. 

 

     For instance, a 73-year-old senior from Queenstown comes together with three neighbours to help 10 other seniors who are either wheelchair-bound or staying alone.  They help to purchase their neighbours' groceries, chit chat with them and bring them out to participate in community programmes together.  In preparation for the recent Lunar New Year, these four kind-hearted neighbours also helped to spring-clean their neighbours' homes.  In time, more of our seniors would be frail, single or without children.  Hence, I cannot emphasise enough the importance of neighbourliness and community support.

 

     How are we trying to foster this?  One avenue is through programmes such as the Wellness Programme.  This encourages

Column: 2836

people to join or even form their own social interest groups.  Through regular social interaction, we hope that some will become close friends and they can lend support to one another in times of need.  Another avenue is through grassroots outreach and activities.  For example, floor parties would be useful to encourage greater interaction among neighbours.  We hope to rekindle the kampong spirit which many older Singaporeans reminisce about in our vertical kampongs today.  MCYS is also harnessing the strengths of voluntary welfare organisations and their volunteers to support the vulnerable and needy.  This include the seniors' activity centres and the befriending programme.  However, we cannot rely entirely on volunteers or the staff to support seniors.  As much as possible, VWO staff can also tap in the good will of neighbours or work with other local community partners, such as the schools, to optimise our limited resources. If we can mobilise community resources more effectively through complement family support, we are one step closer to our vision of ageing-in-place.

     Mr Speaker:  Do you have a supplementary question?

     Mr Laurence Wee Yoke Thong:  Thank you, Minister, for the comprehensive and heartening response to the ageing scene, where we supplement family support as a first line with community support.  Sir, the supplementary question is, will the Government consider, at the opportune time, to give this group of community caregivers some kind of an allowance as incentive and recognition for their efforts?

     Mr Lim Boon Heng:  Sir, I agree that we should recognise these community support groups.  In fact, we do, but not in the monetary sense.  There is a Good Neighbours' Award scheme which is jointly offered by People's Association and HDB.  Most are aware that in different

Column: 2837

constituencies, the grassroots organisations also give their own Good Neighbour Awards

 

 


and these are usually presented at the National Day dinners.  So I think we should do more of this.

LIFTING OF BAN ON SALE OF CHEWING GUM

     5.  Ms Denise Phua Lay Peng asked the Minister for National Development when is the appropriate time for lifting of the ban on the sale of chewing gum in Singapore.

     Dr Mohamad Maliki Bin Osman (for the Minister for National Development):  Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government decided to impose a complete ban on the sale of chewing gum in 1992 due to problems arising from the indiscriminate disposal of gum litter, such as difficulty and cost incurred in removing gum litter from public places, vandalism and service disruptions caused by gum being stuck between doors of MRT trains.  Notwithstanding our general policy to keep Singapore free from chewing gum litter, the Government made an exception in 2004 for sale of chewing gum with therapeutic value as defined under the Medicines Act.  These include those that help smokers quit, or products of dental hygiene.


     Chewing gum litter has not been a significant problem since the ban took effect.   We remain concerned that lifting the ban on the sale of chewing gum could result in chewing gum litter resurfacing as a problem, and undermine our on-going efforts to curb littering.  As the rationale for the imposition of the ban is still valid at present, the Government's position is that the ban should remain.

 

     Mr Speaker:  Yes, Ms Phua, short supplementary question.

     Ms Denise Phua Lay Peng (Jalan Besar):  Thank you, Senior Parliamentary

Column: 2838

Secretary, for the answer.  I am really not so concerned about the chewing gum but really another underlying issue.  If Singaporeans were seeking liberty in so many areas and the Government does concede in some of these areas, then why not liberalise the chewing gum ban?  I am quite perplexed by the fact that people, especially our detractors, remember Singapore for chewing gum ban and caning.  I think this ban that has been effective for almost 20 years now need a review and a rethink.  Let Singaporeans be accountable for the consequences and not be shaped by so many sticks around –  

     Mr Speaker:  Are you are making a speech, Ms Phua?

     Ms Denise Phua Lay Peng:  Surely, Senior Parliamentary Secretary will not consider banning sweets because there are –

     Mr Speaker:  Ask your question and take a seat, Ms Phua. 

     Ms Denise Phua Lay Peng:  – sweet litter or ice cream if there is ice cream stick litter?

     Dr Mohamad Maliki Bin Osman:   Sir, I think we know that Singapore has taken a very pragmatic approach to governance, weighing the cost and benefit of any issue very carefully and making decisions with the interest of Singaporeans at heart.  I think the Government stands by its decision to ban the sale of chewing gum as the rationale is based on maintaining a clean and comfortable living environment for all Singaporeans to enjoy.  Our efforts at creating a clean, green and safe living environment have garnered much more international acclaim than criticism of the ban on chewing gum.  But just to also add littering is still a prevailing problem in Singapore.  We know that there has been increases in education and enforcement efforts but it still is a problem.  So I think going by the experiences and the

Column: 2839

possibilities of disamenities created, at this point of time, we still feel that the ban is necessary.

     Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [22nd February, 2010],

 

Column: 2840

     "That Parliament approves the financial policy of the Government for the financial year 1st April, 2010 to 31st March, 2011." – [Minister for Finance].

 

     Question again proposed.

 

 

 

 

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir):      Sir, some people say that this year's Budget is an election Budget, but I do not think so.  As long as there is increase in GST and the GST is still intact, it is difficult to say that it is going to be an election Budget. 

 

     The increase in GST will hit hardest the lower income group as well as our increasingly marginalized middle income group even with the GST offset measures from the Government which is short term.  I would suggest that the Government take a radical step by reducing the GST by 2% points to rein in inflation which has gone up too high.  I believe that the Government can afford, given that the GST collected accounted for over $6.6 billion or 15% or more of the total revenue, plus additional revenue from the two casinos when they come on stream.

 

     Tax credits only benefit big companies and have limited benefits to borderline companies like SMEs where growth is important and is a constraint to keep momentum going.  Upfront cash or grants is more helpful for SMEs with cash flow problem for them to invest in skills and technology.  The foreign workers' levy could be varied according to industries, like hospitals, old folks homes, hospices that rely a lot on foreign health caregivers which eventually leads to higher operating costs.

 

     I would like to propose the creation of a skills shortage list for short-listing of foreign worker applications.  Create a ranking of skills that have a shortage of labour in Singapore for example, nursing, coaching of certain sport, medical experts

Column: 2841

etc.  With this list and a cap on the number of foreign workers allowed to enter Singapore, work permits will be issued in priority of the shortage in local labour available.  Hence, ensuring that despite placing a cap on the number of foreign workers, industries that require foreign labour due to the shortage of certain skills in Singapore, will still be able to get the workers they need. 

 

     The Ministry of Education – I would like to suggest the Government to peg the increase in tuition fees for tertiary institutions such as polytechnics and universities to the inflation rate or the actual reported increase in operating costs.  This aims to limit the ability of the institutions to raise the fees beyond what is acceptable based on reason. 

 

     Every increase in tuition fees should also be matched with increase in financial aid for needy students so that nobody is left out.  Setting up of a "Work and Study" scheme in tertiary institutions – this scheme allows students to work on cared by the institution and Government.  This helps students finance their education, while gaining useful work experience in a safe and convenient environment.   The last suggestion I would like to make has already been made by Minister Khaw Boon Wan. 

 

     If each individual Singaporean is encouraged to take more personal ownership of their health and lifestyle, perhaps the Government can consider introducing an individual balance score card which the Government could use as a cost saving incentive.  This will be given to individuals to offset expenses in the move to adopting a healthy lifestyle for example, gym membership, medical bills, purchase of exercise equipment, health checks and supplements as well as to redeem benefits such as better insurance

Column: 2842

payments such as the 'no-claim' bonus in the car industry.

 

 

     Ms Audrey Wong Wai Yen (Nominated Member):      Mr Speaker, Sir, I thank you for the opportunity to contribute to this debate. I would like to share a few observations on the topic of productivity, on quality of life for all Singaporeans, and to address the introduction of the foreign workers' levy.

 

     I have no doubt that the issue of Singapore's productivity has to be addressed and have no argument with the need to be more creative and innovative in a changed global economic climate.  Cheaper labour and business costs in other countries have already forced us to adopt new strategies to continue our economic growth.

 

     However, what has not changed is that our key resource is our people.  As such, it is heartening to see that older workers have been singled out for attention and support in this year's Budget as they have worked hard for our nation.  We are hardworking people, but we also want to be fairly treated and attain a decent standard of living.  To attain this decent standard of living, our productivity levels, competitiveness, and attractiveness as a place for business and investment, have to be addressed. But I believe that increasing productivity levels requires more than tax breaks and incentive grants.  It will take more than financial rewards to inspire true innovation and change.  More than these measures, what is essential is a mindset change.  Employers, industry leaders, and workers themselves have to understand what productivity means – in real, practical terms – for themselves and their companies.

 

     Take training, for example.  How exactly does it help a worker's or company's productivity?  This is something that a worker and the company have to look at.  They need a clearer

Column: 2843

understanding of the need for training and the determination and support to make it happen. Simply attending a training course, or sending your workers for such a course, is not a magic pill for better wages and higher productivity.  Many people are sent for training simply because the subsidies and grants are available.  I have heard people complaining about being sent for training "yet again".  Workers should want to be trained or re-trained and understand how this will help their job performance.  At the same time, employers need the skills and smarts to harness the workers' newly acquired knowledge in their line of work.  It can be frustrating for a worker to have attended training or re-skilling, and then return to the same old job without the opportunity to apply their learning.

 

     Furthermore, Singaporeans are so used to having their training paid for by employers and the Government that perhaps we do not necessarily have the incentive to seek out training opportunities on our own.  Hence there is less motivation to improve. 

 

 

But we know there are exceptions to this as we have heard many stories of people who have gone for training and re-skilling and have better jobs even in the debates in this House in the last few days.  Another disincentive to training is the long hours we already put in at the workplace, and in some companies the heavy workload per worker which leaves little time for additional training and even can lead to mental fatigue. If we take training for granted, if employer and worker attitudes do not change, then our productivity levels would not increase.

 

     In this context, I would like to share some remarks that I read in the Business Times by Mr Kenny Yap, who is Executive Chairman of Qian Hu. Mr Yap said, "My experience tells me that the difference between Singaporeans and foreign workers is attitude. Most foreign workers are dead serious about working, whereas

Column: 2844

quite a few young Singaporeans force themselves to work.  My gut feeling is, if we cannot find a way to change the working attitude, it is going to be a tall order."  Mr Yap also commented that, "to raise the productivity of the whole team, we must upgrade all of the team members' skills. By this logic, only subsidising local workers training defeats the purpose of building a team. As far as the company is concerned, if you are good, you are good regardless of whether you are a Singaporean or foreigner."

 

     Sir, Mr Yap's point is that, when we look at measures to increase overall productivity, there are other factors in the work environment and business landscape to consider.  Mr Yap refers to something other Members of the House have already raised: the reluctance of Singaporeans to take on jobs that involve long hours, shift work or manual labour. The irony is that while we shun these jobs, we also worry about the influx of foreign workers whom employers have resorted to hiring.  For instance, the bus companies having to hire foreigners to drive our public buses, as described by Mr Ong Ah Heng.  Now, I personally believe that bus driving is an honourable profession as it provides a valuable public service – I am a regular bus commuter myself – and the unions have done much to beef up the training and professionalism of the job.  I will elaborate on this point about upgrading the image of certain jobs a little later.

 

    Mr Kenny Yap also makes the point that if Singaporean and foreign workers are needed to work on the same team, it is the entire work process that matters. If Singaporeans are re-trained to better standards, how can this be harnessed with their foreign colleagues' skill levels so that the entire team's work process becomes more efficient and productive?  The implication here – and it is an important one – is that management and employers play a very important part in organising or innovating these work

Column: 2845

processes. Perhaps, management and employers also need further support in this area.

 

     A further important factor in raising productivity is actually the human factor. A happy worker is a productive worker. Thus, it is crucial for companies to provide a happy work environment where workers look forward to going to work, morale is good, bosses are compassionate, interpersonal conflict is minimised, talent is recognised and rewarded, staff welfare is taken seriously, workers' suggestions are taken on board and, of course, providing a healthy work-life balance. Good management practices and leadership are essential.

 

     Since the setting up of the Tripartite Committee on Work-Life Strategy in 2000, Singapore has made  progress in encouraging companies to be family-friendly. The Ministry of Manpower's website has a section dedicated to Work-Life Balance, where it notes the business benefits that result from a successful work-life strategy – these have been found in other research.  They include increased productivity; improved recruitment and retention which means also lower cost in terms of recruitment of staff as there is lower staff turnover; lower absenteeism rates; improved customer experience and a more motivated, satisfied and equitable workforce.

 

     So what more can we do to encourage these "softer" aspects of enhancing productivity? In addition to work-life strategies, what other measures can we encourage employers to adopt in order to maintain a positive and productive work environment?

 

     Having a good work-life balance certainly improves our quality of life. And when we talk about improving the quality of life for all Singaporeans, we cannot

Column: 2846

forget those among us who are likely to remain in low-skilled, low-wage jobs for a long time. I think we cannot escape the fact that these jobs will always be around. What quality of life can these workers expect in, say, five years from now? How much can, say, a cleaner expect to earn in five years' time? Can companies offer wages to the lowest-ranked workers in a way that keeps up with the inflation rate?  Will they share their gains from productivity increases in an equitable manner with their employees? 

 

     Employers will have to anticipate that salaries will need to increase with inflation over time and find ways to harness improvements in productivity to covering these business costs. One way to do this is job redesign and, of course, investing in training and innovation. But, perhaps more importantly, it is not only about employers.  It is about society as a whole.  We need to re-value these jobs. It is time for us to change our attitudes towards these so-called "dirty jobs" – those that involve manual labour.

 

     Instead of looking down on these jobs, we should appreciate that they are vital aspects of our economy and workers need to feel that they are respected for the work that they do. This kind of re-valuing demands a sea-change in our mindsets and attitudes. Singaporeans have often observed that in western countries, workers in lower-skilled jobs such as hospital cleaners have a different attitude and carry themselves differently – they see themselves as holding down a proper job, with proper pay and benefits, and more importantly able to raise a family. These are quality of life markers that matter to the ordinary citizen. But as we have heard in the past few days, there are still many families in need in Singapore and those stresses they face and we cannot discount them.  In Singapore, we have some examples of how job redesign and training have contributed to changing the perceptions of certain jobs, for

Column: 2847

example, security guards. Training programmes driven by the WDA, unions and industry have led to better trained security guards and recognition as a profession, which leads to pride in their jobs and better salaries. I hope that WDA, the unions and employers will continue in this fashion and help more lower-wage workers attain a better quality of life.

 

     Yesterday's Straits Times carried two interesting articles about two workers – a carpenter in Japan and a bricklayer in Australia – which showed how these "manual labour" jobs have attained societal respect. The article on the bricklayer had the headline "This job is an art and a career". The word "art" in this context is interesting but true.  It takes training, expertise, attention to detail and care to lay the bricks in an even and straight line, and that is what we would call "quality finish".  It all ends up in a beautifully-constructed building. In Singapore, on the other hand, one of the barriers we face in attracting people to such work is that we no longer have this appreciation for the work of the hands, for things like carpentry, woodworking, metal working and bricklaying.  Even bus driving, it seems, falls into this category. The work of the hands is what we could call "craft", and is related to artistry. For instance, every handmade piece of furniture is unique and carries the mark of its maker. I would like to suggest that it is time we start to understand such craft again.  Perhaps, in fact, we can even draw on the arts sector, on traditional and modern artisans and artists to build up this appreciation and enhance the image of jobs that require hardwork with the hands. Perhaps, they can help to educate the young on the value of handiwork. When our appreciation of manual labour rises, the standing of those who perform these jobs should rise too. So, perhaps, this is something that the Ministry of Education or policy makers could consider.  Certainly, in my profession, I have met many people who fabricate things or

Column: 2848

do manual labour – carpenters, electricians, movers – and I respect what they do. They have specialised knowledge that I certainly do not possess, and without which the show cannot go on!

 

     Another way that we could re-value jobs is to devise other ways of calculating their value, such as the social and community benefits created through particular jobs. I was just reading an interesting article on BBC news from December last year about a research from the New Economics Foundation in the UK, where various jobs were evaluated according to the total contribution they made to society, such as the impact on communities and the environment, and it was found that hospital cleaners created £10 of value for every £1 they are paid, whereas in this research bankers destroy £7 of value for every £1 they earn! I do not know how the numbers were calculated, but this was carried in a number of news reports.  Perhaps, our policy makers could look into such an index for blue collar jobs to broaden our perspectives.  

 

    A final point about training is on contract and freelance workers.  I think that should be easy avenues for them to pursue retraining and re-skilling as well. 

 

     For too long now, we have relied on foreign migrant labour to fill low-skilled and low-wage positions, and it is clear we cannot afford to continue with this assumption.

 

     I would now like to raise concerns about the increased foreign workers' levy. Because I can imagine that the trigger response of some contractors who employ large numbers of foreign workers will be to seek the fastest solution to an increase in business cost. This could result in a few worst-case scenario responses by employers which will end up hurting the workers.  For instance, the increased levy is passed on to workers

Column: 2849

which may be in the form of illegal kickbacks or salary deductions; labour agencies increase their fees for finding jobs for workers; employers cut corners by dismissing workers before their contracts are up; and cutting corners may also result in safety lapses – with fewer workers, they may have to work longer hours, or there may be less than the optimum number of workers to carry out a dangerous task, and that could result in injury or death.

 

     Simply put, when it comes to money, unfortunately for a lot of human beings, we are willing to risk prosecution.  The recent prosecutions of contractors who accepted kickbacks, which have been widely reported in the media, are testament to this. Those who provide welfare services to foreign migrant labour regularly report that there are many cases of illegal, exploitative and unsafe practices that go unreported for many reasons.  So with the increase in foreign workers' levy, we might have some unintended consequences.  Will the Ministry of Manpower have to work even harder to root out errant employers? I urge the Ministry of Manpower to pay close attention to the impact of the foreign workers' levy on companies that hire large numbers of foreign workers, and ensure that errant employers are brought to justice. I would also like to suggest that part of the increased foreign workers' levy could be channelled towards training, integration and welfare programmes for migrant workers who have also contributed to our development. It will be to Singapore's benefit for us to be more vigilant in ensuring that migrant labour is treated fairly and humanely.

 

     While Singaporeans are understandably concerned about the pressures on space, transport and housing caused by the large population of foreigners, perhaps we also need to be more

Column: 2850

balanced in considering the issue. It is an emotive issue. I think we need to be careful not to go overboard in our complaints.  After all, we are a society that is multi-cultural and diverse.  Yes, PRs may have contributed to the rise in demand for flats leading to high housing prices, but do not forget that Singaporeans too sold their flats to PRs and therefore a number of Singaporeans have actually benefited from this, just as others have found themselves on the losing end.

 

     Ultimately, what Singaporeans need to do is to shift our work culture attitudes where better productivity is not about working longer hours and where there is work-life balance and where human factors count.

 

     Sir, the Budget and the recommendations of the ESC are a step towards dealing with some entrenched issues within our economy and workforce and I hope that Singaporeans will strive together for a better quality of life and inclusive growth for all.  I will end by telling a story about Switzerland as that comparison has come up a few times during the debate. Two Swiss artists came to Singapore for an art project that I organised, they stayed in Singapore for three weeks, and they loved our country. What made a deep impression on them?  Our multilingualism, multiculturalism and the fact that diverse races and religions co-exist in peace and harmony. They told me that they would not encounter such a rich diversity of cultures where they live, and said: "This is very important, it gives Singapore strength and uniqueness, don’t take it for granted".

 

 

Singapore has faced many challenges in the past and by uniting as a people, we have overcome difficulties and made the country what it is today. Perhaps, not quite Switzerland yet, but still, I think we have done pretty well. We cannot take our resilience and unity for granted and we certainly have to address gaps such as the growing income disparity.  But what we have, I believe, 

Column: 2851

stand us in good stead as we head into the future.

 

12.45 pm

 

     Miss Penny Low (Pasir Ris-Punggol): Sir, in the past 40 years, simply put, our growth strategy was one of  "more input, more output". 

 

    First, we mobilised our own land and labour resources and attracted foreign capital and entrepreneurs. Then, when we expanded land by building upwards and labour by importing more cheap workforce. Over the decades, labour force participation rate reached a high 80%, for ages 20-59 years old, quality of life improved and the cost of living escalated. But meanwhile, this same old method of increasing input to increase output seems to have reached a diminishing marginal return.  So this year's Budget focused on increasing productivity, spearing global SMEs from Singapore and an inclusive growth.

 

    But yet, feedback from the GPC Resource Panel, trade associations and businessmen pointed to the fact that change means uncertainties and uncertainties is not good for business.  Many businessmen also said that they know how to maximise every factor of production so there is no need for the Government to interfere. Some in the hospitality and construction industries even criticised the Government for not being truly understanding to their operational limitations, and that the new levy rules would severely impact their business. 

 

    But, Sir, global tides are changing at real time, and we must avoid the frog-in-boiling water syndrome, waking up one day, only to ask "who moved my cheese?", when it is too little, too late.

 

     European supermarkets offer us some lessons. Many have digital price display

Column: 2852

panels alongside barcode scanners that provides information about the goods on the well-stocked shelves. Since all products do come with barcodes, there is no longer a need to physically tag every item and change tags when there is a price change, greatly reducing the need for manual manpower. In Japan, all 7-Elevens have additional pictorial keys on their Point of Sales (POS) system. Once, a 65-year-old smiled as I self-scanned my purchase, while she pressed some pictorial buttons which indicated my age, gender and build. She was collecting shoppers' data so she can have an accurate picture of her clients' purchase habits, frequency and time of purchase so that she can better plan her cashflow and manpower needs. She also makes more money from selling the data to manufacturers, who will use it for better product launches specific to that locality.

 

    In Singapore, the National Library is way ahead of the curve. With its bold and innovative use of technology, some regional libraries now have only one frontline staff.

 

    One of my grassroots leader, Mr Jeffrey Low, from Meng Soon Paints and Hardware Trading Company, recently invested in a computerised pre-programme paint tinting machine.  He said that it has increased efficiency of his business operations significantly because before that, when there were special paint colour orders, he would have to take it down to the paint supplier personally and wait for about three days before he got his order confirmed.  And sometimes, because the quantity is too little, the order is turned down and he loses the business.  But now, with this machine, he said that he can cut down on the supply chain for customised requests immediately thereby increasing efficiency, sales and of course, giving him a lot more free time to do and focus on growing his business. 

 

    

Column: 2853

So indeed, improved productivity can spur economic growth, but we must remember that they are only a means to an end, and not the end in itself.  So what is the end? Workers are not just a statistic on a business or Government chart. Every person deserves to be facilitated to become the best that they can be in whichever field that they choose. 

 

    Sir, Google recently won the accolade of having the highest value-add per worker at $450,000 at the second quarter of 2009. Not only that, it is said that they receive one million job applicants a year and denies some 99.5% of them. How did they do that?  There is no time to elaborate here, but a complete redesign of the workplace and workflow, making Google Town the place to work, play and live in, while offering space and flexibility for workers to work on their dream technology seems to be the trick. In short, they kept morale and aspirations high, and drives employees to be the best they can be. The question is:  can we do the same for Singapore and Singaporeans?  Can the Government act as a facilitator and create an incentive framework that encourages everyone, every enterprise to be the best that we can be.

 

    Yes, we can, and I think, in fact, we might have done so for the top half of the population, but I cannot say the same for the bottom half. I was heartened to read that an inclusive growth was the third thrust of this Budget. But upon closer examination, I was dismayed to see that it refers very narrowly, to increasing productivity and income of the low-wage workers. What about the no wage workers?  What about the marginalised latent resources that could have been further disadvantaged because we had unknowingly built an environment that further isolates them? For example, without MND's recent effort in ensuring barrier-free access for all roads and buildings, the physically handicapped, the

Column: 2854

old, the weak and the heavily pregnant will find navigating roads difficult, and in another 20 years when the ageing population explodes, we will have a good proportion of the population sitting at home.  But with the barrier-free access and low step buses, they can continue to be mobile and continue with gainful employment, contributing to growth with dignity.  

 

     Once, I was at the launch of a universal access website by a disabled people's association. At the welcome speech, the president said, "Imagine a world where the visually impaired can file their tax returns online". Just then, it hit me that I have been e-filing my taxes for years, but they had no access, even though universal web access is inexpensive and has been around for sometime. Then it occurred to me that they did not need it any way, because to start with, they have no income to file. Yet, like savants who have been found to have super-human abilities because their brains block out some other functions, the blind has a profound sense of hearing and touch beyond that of a normal being. The same can be said of many other marginalised groups, be it the autistic, hearing impaired, depressed, elderly or lowly educated. Can policy makers design incentive frameworks that encourage the deepening and employment of such super skill sets? It will up productivity if a square peg is fitted in a square hole. Now, by giving wage subsidy to companies to employ any disabled is not only a handout approach, but one that does not incentivise people nor company to operate at their best.

 

     Another example, Mr Dennis Kweh, an National Library Board (NLB) staff, suffered from a rare genetic disorder called Morquio-Brailsford Disease, Spinal Sclerosis and blinded on one eye due to glaucoma.  He started Adventure 200, a 200-kilometre wheelchair marathon over three days, to raise $200,000 for the

Column: 2855

Spastic Children's Association of Singapore.  I wheelchaired alongside Dennis at the start and end of the marathon and saw how he toiled every distance, stopping only for a doctor to check that he is fit to carry on. Yet, the event was not very well supported because Dennis is not an Olympian nor a super star, and there is certainly no big prize money at the end of it for him when he completes the trip. However, his effort is no less than that of an Olympian. How can we support his effort? How can ordinary Singaporeans support his effort to be a net contributor to society, despite his own very difficult conditions? 

 

     For too long, while in a rat race, the world has accepted a widening bell curve approach to development, rising Gini coefficient was acceptable, and economic growth does not have to account for externalities. Perhaps that was necessary to get majority up to speed in the shortest possible time. But history is a mirror, and externalities, be it social or environment, will boomerang in our face, if we refuse to heed the lessons of the global recession.

 

     Sir, we are not all responsible for the past, but we are all responsible for the future, and for the world we leave for our children. I repeat my Budget call last year, when Iceland and the Artic Ice melted together that the right question to ask is not "when the downturn will be over", but "how would we want to emerge from this storm – as a person, as a corporation, and as a nation"?  The right lessons must be learnt. We need to re-value our goals, which cannot be just a pure GDP race.  We need to redesign the policy incentive framework to be truly inclusive, and rebuild the KPIs and institutions to support them. What gets measured, gets done. It is not an issue for the economists to worry about.  It concerns all of us.  So I have three wishes for this Budget, in building an inclusive growth.  

 

 

   

Column: 2856

Wish number one – I hope that the National Productivity and Continuing Education Council will involve not only the union, the public and the business sector, but also the people or the non-profit-organisation sector, who also needs a leg up.

 

   Wish number two – making of what I call, a WikiMe. I understand that the Government promotes mass collaboration between multiple Government agencies and businesses. The impending One Map is one example, where Government agencies and businesses can make their facilities and services available through a map interface. I propose the we create another map, which I call 'WikiMe', meaning Wikipedia and me where the Government creates the infrastructure like how we created Wireless@SG, and templates, while people upload their own content, offering information about themselves, exchange triumphs and tribulations, and even offering a hand for free or for a fee. If done properly, this could be the largest and single most effective way of self-help and neighbourhood bonding mechanism that could inform the neighbours of who are around them, who is available to be a babysitter, run an errand or be a handy man.  Productivity will rise, as latent resources like homemakers and elderly who may not want to work long hours and only want to work on jobs to home, can now be meaningfully employed.

 

     My final wish is that for the Youth Olympics Games (YOG).  This is an inaugural event in the world, and one that Singapore will possibly host once for a long time to come. August is only five months away, and yet, there does not seem to be very much buzz in the air. In contrast, Glasgow won the bid to host the Commonwealth Games 2014.  Yet, when I visited it last November, people were excited about it. Why? The answer is found in the search results page. When you google the YOG page, that is the

Column: 2857

YOG site, the search results turned up words like "volunteer", "sports", "YOG", "events". But the Glasgow Commonwealth Games, abbreviated GCG, turned up words like "getting involved", "our people", "what Games mean to Glasgow", and so on.

 

     Sir, a language reflects the dominant thought of the organiser. While both Glasgow and Singapore rallied the people to support the Games, Glasgow made the game relevant to the people. First, I understand from the Mayor he had to go to the Chambers to ask for taxpayers' money to bid for the Games. When he won the bid, he set up multiple feedback and suggestion portals, to understand how the Scotts would like to spend that money. As it turns out, seemingly unrelated wishes like improving public transport, more low-cost housing and so on topped the list.  The GCG website states that, "One of the benefits of hosting the Commonwealth Games is to leave the host city with a lasting legacy of improved infrastructure that is both positive and sustainable. Glasgow will be rolling up its sleeves to ensure that everyone involved with the Games has a fantastic time. But the Commonwealth Games means so much more  – it is the once-in-a-generation opportunity to regenerate a derelict part of the city and tackle some of the issues of health and deprivation that have blighted Glasgow."  It went on to say that, "Members of Glasgow City Council and the Scottish Government are working on plans to ensure the Games leave a positive legacy on our communities."

 

     Amongst others, Glasgow is working on a comprehensive transport system that covers the city and extends to the expressways that connects the country, while the Commonwealth Game Village will be built and converted to 300 low-cost social housing units and a 120-bed

Column: 2858

care home. This is relevant and real connection with the people and responsible use of taxpayers' money. This is also why while Glasgow is cheering while the Games are four years away, our streets are still quiet while the clock is ticking away. If people welcome the Games, they will embrace the athletes with open arms and genuine smiles. People need to understand what the Games mean to them, we need to involve everyone in this historical event.  We still have five months so it is still not too late.  I urge the organisers to make this event the Singapore moment where everyone counts.  I also urge that everyone, individuals or enterprise rally around the YOG and stand up for Singapore.

 

 

     In conclusion, Sir, during the downturn, many global MNCs suddenly discovered that they have a nationality. Similarly, many people discovered they have a welfare pass via their passport. Only in our own homeland, are we first class citizens. While, we need to return the economy to the service of its people, people too, need to return to the country the dignity of being the best and the spirit of self reliance, and people need to return to each other, the humanity that binds us all. Sir, in the spirit of taking this opportunity to re-value, redesign and rebuild our society, let us strive towards a more inclusive, sustainable and better future, ming tian hui gen hao (明天会更好).

 

 

     The Minister for Manpower (Mr Gan Kim Yong): Yesterday, Deputy Prime Minister Teo talked about the National Productivity and Continuity Education Council and our strategy on raising productivity to achieve sustainable and inclusive economic growth. I will talk more about Ministry of Manpower's strategy during the COS. But let me just focus on one particular area this afternoon. To make the strategic shift, we are making adjustments to the foreign worker levy to encourage employers to use their foreign workers more efficiently and to motivate them to

Column: 2859

invest in productivity improvements. I think it is useful to share with Members the thinking behind the levy changes and respond to some Members' concerns about these changes. First, let me thank Members for their comments and support of the changes.


     We have taken a calibrated approach in adjusting the levy, so as to maintain a balance between supporting economic growth and ensuring that we do not become over-reliant on foreign manpower. As Ms Jessica Tan has pointed out, we must ensure that Singapore remains as an attractive place for businesses so that we can continue to create jobs for our workers. That is why we have not reduced the top line Dependency Ratio so that growth companies can have access to foreign workers they critically need to support their operation and expansion. This will also allow us to attract high value new investments that will raise our productivity, spur our growth and create good jobs for Singaporeans.


     However, we cannot continue to grow our foreign workforce at the same pace we did in recent years. We need to moderate the overall inflow of foreign workers and motivate companies to invest in productivity improvements. To achieve this, starting from 1st July 2010, we will increase levies across the board and adjust the levy tiers. Let me explain how this works. The levy tiers are structured such that the higher a company's dependency on foreign workers, the higher the levy rate and the bigger the levy bill it will have to bear. For example, a services company with 10 local workers may employ up to 10 Work Permit holders because the Dependency Ratio is 50% – 10 locals for 10 foreign workers. Let us assume that the foreign workers are all skilled workers to simplify the example. The first Work Permit holder it employs will be subject to a levy of $160 from 1st July 2010. It will pay $160 levy for each of the Work Permit holder it employs up

Column: 2860

to a total of five. That is the first tier. However, the sixth Work Permit holder it employs will be subject to a levy of $300, and the ninth Work Permit holder will be subject to a levy of $450.  That is the second tier and the third tier.  We will further tighten the levy tiers over the next three years. This way, companies will have a strong incentive to reduce their dependence on foreign workers.


     A number of Members, including Mr Liang Eng Hwa, Mr Teo Siong Seng, Mr Sin Boon Ann, Mdm Ho Geok Choo, Dr Amy Khor and Mr Michael Palmer, have expressed concern about the impact of foreign levy changes on businesses, especially the SMEs. Let me stress that the levy changes should not be viewed in isolation. They should be seen in the light of the various initiatives and measures announced by Finance Minister Tharman to help companies, especially SMEs, to improve productivity. As Deputy Prime Minister Teo mentioned yesterday, productivity is not just about cost reduction and efficiency, it is also about how businesses can create value. I will not elaborate further as the Ministry of Trade and Industry will address how it intends to assist SMEs at a later stage.


     Ms Jessica Tan and Dr Ahmad Magad have also cautioned that some companies may not be able to implement productivity improvements immediately. Mr Michael Palmer has also asked if we could align the pace of the levy changes to the 10-year productivity target. We understand that companies will need time to adjust.  This is why the levy changes will be implemented in steps over three years. The first increase in levy rates on 1st July 2010 will be a modest one, ranging between $10 and $30 for most Work Permit holders. This represents an average of less than half a percent of the overall wage bill. But we need to get companies to start thinking about improving the productivity and take steps to reduce their dependency on foreign manpower now,

Column: 2861

so that they have enough time to realise productivity gains. The longer we delay, the more painful the adjustment will be later.


     Several Members, such as Mr Teo Siong Seng, Ms Irene Ng, Dr Ahmad Magad, Mr Ong Ah Heng, Mr Sin Boon Ann, Mdm Ho Geok Choo, Dr Amy Khor and Mr Zainul Abidin Rasheed are also concerned that some jobs may be shunned by locals and companies may have difficulties in recruiting enough locals to replace the foreign workers. Let me clarify of the aim of the levy changes is to motivate companies to increase their productivity and deliver higher value-added products and services with fewer foreign workers. The increase in levies alone will not necessarily lead to productivity improvements if companies merely replace foreign workers with locals and employ the same number of workers. Let me borrow a phrase from a colleague, Mr Lim Swee Say, "with same-same input and same-same output, productivity will remain same-same, with no real improvements". Companies should consider how they can streamline business processes, improve their products and services, explore new markets with higher value and upgrade the skills of their workforce. This way, they will see real productivity gains.


     Mr Low Thia Khiang has suggested that we remove the foreign worker levy completely and use Dependency Ratios instead as the sole lever to control the foreign worker numbers. Let me explain why we need the two levers – Dependency Ratios and foreign worker levy – to work in tandem to moderate demand for foreign workers and allocate them efficiently. If we use Dependency Ratio alone to regulate demand for foreign workers, we will need to reduce it significantly. I have earlier explained why this could impact high value growth

Column: 2862

companies and new investments that may require foreign workers. The challenge is how we can support these high growth companies and new investments without increasing the total number of foreign workers here.  The issue is therefore one of allocation. We want to encourage companies which can operate with fewer foreign workers to reduce their dependence, while those who need more will have to pay a higher levy rate but still keeping within the overall Dependency Ratio requirement. I have illustrated earlier how the levy works to achieve this. If we only have Dependency Ratio system with no levy, it would not make much of a difference to a company, like the example I gave just now, whether it hires one foreign worker or 10 foreign workers. In the end, most companies may well decide to hire as many foreign workers as they can, right up to the limit of their Dependency Ratios. This will be contrary to our objective to moderate demand and facilitate efficient allocation of foreign manpower resources.


     Therefore as Mrs Josephine Teo has pointed out the Dependency Ratio system requires an accompanying pricing mechanism to allocate foreign workers. Mr Low has initially suggested adjusting the Dependency Ratio by industries to achieve this.  The question is how can the Government be in a position to decide which industries are more deserving of foreign workers? For example, how do we determine whether the pharmaceutical industry requires more or fewer foreign workers than say, the food industry? Even within the same industry, food and beverage, for example – how do we decide whether a coffee shop requires more or fewer foreign workers than, say, a French restaurant? So instead of the Government making decisions on the number of foreign workers in each industry, each business and each company, we should leave it to market forces to do that through a pricing mechanism. In fact, Mr Low conceded as

Column: 2863

much when he subsequently suggested a "COE" system to allocate foreign workers, which, in fact, is another form of pricing mechanism. However a "COE" allocation system for foreign workers is fraught with many difficulties. For one, it creates uncertainty for employers, in terms of price and availability of foreign workers. The "COE" system would be no simpler than the levy system and could end up creating other problems.

The writer is Mr Otto Fong – not our Mr Arthur Fong – son of the former Secretary-General of the Singapore Bus Workers' Union, who was involved in the Hock Lee bus riots in 1955.  Mr Fong Swee Suan was a leftist member of the PAP and, later on, he became a political detainee.  After his release from detention, Mr Fong Swee Suan and his family settled in Johor Baru.  Mr Otto Fong and his siblings travelled daily from across the Causeway to study in Singapore.  He would get up 5.00 am and returned home only after 3.00 pm.  Life was not easy for him. 

 

     He goes on to say, and I quote:

 

     "In my own youth, I blamed both men for my imperfect Life.  Fortunately, age gave me new perspectives.  If I do not make a better life for myself, I am the only one to blame.  Just as MM Lee’s generation had worked hard for me, I must now work hard for my own future.  Whether Singapore ups its game to another level is not up to my father’s generation. It is up to mine."

 

     Sir, this is a fine example of a boy turning into a man and, in the process,

Column: 2924

developing a forgiving attitude and a very balanced perspective.   I quote Otto Fong because he has shown the spirit of "live and let live", despite his own imperfect life in his youth.

 

     Sir, I had spoken earlier about how Singaporeans ourselves need to find that special something to cherish and the need to love our fellow Singaporeans.   Now, I would like to talk about the new arrivals who come to Singapore to start their lives anew.  While there have been a lot of discussions on the issues of locals versus foreigners and so on, I would, however, just want to share three stories which highlight the impact of foreign talent and workers, both in Singapore and other countries.

 

     First, in the past, I remember we could only eat Malay and Indian food during Chinese New Year period as most Chinese would close their stalls to celebrate Chinese New Year.  Since opening up to foreign labour, many Chinese restaurants and hawker stalls are opened during the Chinese New Year period because of the foreigner workers from China and their presence has also spurred some of the Singaporeans stall owners to open their stall as well.  So, having foreign workers among us has helped us to improve our living comfort. 

 

     Second, I met a China Minister last year and asked him why China needs to attract foreign talent when it has already had 1.3 billion of population.  His reply was that for China to compete with the world, it needs the best from the world.  When China does not have such talents, it will seek them out from the world.  I am not surprised that if this talent search also includes Singaporeans. 

 

     Third, I was in Tokyo last month for work when having a bowl of noodles in an eating house, I noticed that some of the waitresses did not quite look like Japanese.  So, when I asked one of them,

Column: 2925

in Mandarin, she responded and told me that she and her many of her colleagues were actually from China.  Later, when I asked the senior executive of the big Japanese corporation about this, he said many Japanese are no longer willing to work as waiters and waitresses.  Even if they do, their salaries will be much higher than foreign workers.  He then whispered into my ear and said that if not for these foreign workers, he would have paid much more for his noodles.  So, while Japan is quite a closed society, many Japanese quietly welcome foreign workers as they help to bring costs down and make life easier.

     Singapore only has about five million people.  We need talents and we need them from the world.  The alternative is a lower standard of our own game, a less comfortable living and a loss of international competitiveness.  All these points have been well argued during the debate in the last two days.  Hence, I shall not belabour them further.

 

     Sir, although these arguments are well won, the fact remains that one-third of our current workforce is made up of foreign workers, and we know that we need them while we embark on a challenging path to raise our productivity by one-third in the next 10 years.  Since we cannot wish the foreign workers or foreign talents away because we need them, I think the next best thing to do is to think afresh about what we can do to help foreign talents better integrate into our Singapore community.

 

     First, I want to suggest that the whole notion of national integration is to go beyond race and religion, beyond locals and foreigners.  National integration should also include intra-social bonding between the haves and the have-nots to bridge the

Column: 2926

gap, to stop the breeding-of-the-caste mentality.

 

     Sir, we know that since January 2002, Inter-Racial Confidence Circles (IRCCs) were set up for constituencies, and Harmony Circles for schools, workplaces and other local organisations.  There are altogether 84 constituencies in Singapore and there is one IRCC in each constituency.  There are also many Harmony Circles out there in the community.  What I would like to propose is this – that the IRCCs consider expanding its scope to include intra-social bonding in our society for the purpose mentioned earlier in my speech.

 

     On the other hand, the Harmony Circles in companies, schools and elsewhere take into their job scope the integration of new Singaporeans.  I would also like to propose additional funding mechanisms and strong support for this expanded role and job scope for the IRCCs and Harmony Circles.  There are justifications to do so.

 

     Sir, no one knows how well this will work, and I think we will need to refine the idea further.  But I do believe that we need to work on old Singaporeans via the IRCCs while at the same time bring a fresh approach to the national integration efforts for the new Singaporeans through the Harmony Circles.

 

     Sir, all of us in this House carry a flame for Singapore and we all want to do it proud and graciously, regardless of our race, language, our achievements and our social standing.  Like what Mr Otto Fong said, it is up to our generation – Singaporeans old and new – to make Singapore the land of our dreams.
